tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: The question requires calculating the equivalence ratio, which involves understanding stoichiometry, fuel-air ratio, and atomic weights. It's a multi-step calculation involving multiple concepts, making it a medium-hard numerical problem.

answer_validation.reasoning: Equivalence ratio is defined as \(\phi = (F/A)_\text{actual} / (F/A)_\text{stoich}\), where F/A is fuel-to-air mass ratio. From the given stoichiometric reaction 2C\_8H\_{18} + (25O\_2 + 94N\_2) \to 16CO\_2 + 18H\_2O + 94N\_2, we first compute the stoichiometric fuel-air mass ratio. Molar mass of octane: \(M\_{C_8H_{18}} = 8\times12 + 18\times1 = 114\,\text{kg/kmol}\). Molar mass of air in the reaction: 25 kmol O\_2 and 94 kmol N\_2, so mass of air per 2 kmol fuel is \(m\_\text{air} = 25\times32 + 94\times28 = 800 + 2632 = 3432\,\text{kg}\). Mass of fuel per 2 kmol is \(m\_f = 2\times114 = 228\,\text{kg}\). Thus stoichiometric fuel-air ratio is \((F/A)\_\text{stoich} = 228/3432 \approx 0.0664\). Given actual fuel-air ratio is 0.028. Therefore \(\phi = 0.028 / 0.0664 \approx 0.4217\), which matches option B (0.422).

step_by_step: Identify that equivalence ratio is defined using fuel-to-air mass ratios: \(\phi = (F/A)_\text{actual} / (F/A)_\text{stoich}\).
From the balanced stoichiometric equation, compute molar masses: octane C\_8H\_{18} has molar mass 114 kg/kmol; O\_2 is 32 kg/kmol; N\_2 is 28 kg/kmol.

Compute total mass of fuel and air in the stoichiometric equation: for 2 kmol fuel, mass of fuel is 2\times114 = 228 kg; air has 25 kmol O\_2 and 94 kmol N\_2, so mass of air is 25\times32 + 94\times28 = 3432 kg.
Use the given actual fuel-air ratio 0.028 to compute equivalence ratio: \(\phi = 0.028 / 0.0664 \approx 0.422\).
Match with the closest option: 0.422 corresponds to option B.

topic.name: Combustion and thermochemistry
topic.syllabus_ref: Section 6 Propulsion -> Combustion, stoichiometry, fuel-air ratio, equivalence ratio

concepts.name: Fuel-air mass ratio vs molar ratio

essential: Definition of equivalence ratio in combustion
Conversion between moles and mass using molar mass
Reading and interpreting balanced chemical equations
Difference between fuel-air and air-fuel ratios
helpful: Typical composition of air as O2 and N2
Understanding of stoichiometric combustion for hydrocarbons

Main Concept: requires: Ability to compute stoichiometric fuel-air ratio from a balanced equation
enables: Analysis of lean and rich combustion conditions
enables: Design and performance analysis of combustors and engines

difficulty_factors: Requires careful distinction between fuel-air and air-fuel ratios
Needs correct computation of molar masses and total air mass from the reaction

textbook_references.author: D.P. Mishra
textbook_references.section: Stoichiometry, equivalence ratio and fuel-air ratio

textbook_references.author: P.K. Nag
textbook_references.section: Stoichiometric air-fuel ratio and equivalence ratio
textbook_references.text_snippet: The stoichiometric A/F ratio is a critical design parameter for engines, defining the ideal operating point for complete fuel utilization.

video_references.topic_covered: Stoichiometric mixture, air-fuel ratio, and equivalence ratio for hydrocarbons
Practical combustion analysis, actual air-fuel ratio and equivalence ratio from exhaust gas

step_by_step_solution.solution_path: Use balanced stoichiometric equation to get stoichiometric fuel-air mass ratio, then apply definition of equivalence ratio using given actual fuel-air ratio.
key_insights: Equivalence ratio is based on fuel-to-air mass ratio, not air-to-fuel.
The given balanced equation already represents stoichiometric combustion, so its fuel and air masses directly give the stoichiometric ratio.

formulas_principles.name: Equivalence ratio definition
formulas_principles.conditions: Applies to any premixed fuel-oxidizer system when fuel-air ratios are expressed on a mass basis.
formulas_principles.relevance: Core formula to compute the equivalence ratio from given fuel-air ratios.

formulas_principles.name: Stoichiometric fuel-air ratio from masses
formulas_principles.conditions: Masses obtained from a balanced stoichiometric chemical equation.
formulas_principles.relevance: Used to compute stoichiometric fuel-air ratio from the given reaction.

formulas_principles.name: Mass-mole relation
formulas_principles.conditions: n is amount of substance in kmol, M is molar mass in kg/kmol, m is mass in kg.
formulas_principles.relevance: Converts stoichiometric coefficients (kmol) into masses for fuel and air.

industry_examples: Design of gas turbine combustors where operating equivalence ratio determines flame temperature, emissions, and stability.
Calibration of aircraft piston engines, where mixture control leans or enriches the equivalence ratio for performance and fuel economy.
specific_systems: Turbofan engine combustors in commercial airliners operating at lean equivalence ratios for NOx control.
Afterburners in military jet engines operating at near-stoichiometric or slightly rich equivalence ratios for maximum thrust.
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Knowing equivalence ratio from a given fuel-air ratio is essential for predicting adiabatic flame temperature, pollutant formation, and ensuring safe, efficient operation of propulsion systems.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using air-to-fuel ratio instead of fuel-to-air ratio in the equivalence ratio formula, effectively inverting the ratio.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Students often memorize A/F terminology and forget that the definition of \(\phi\) is based on F/A.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Remember the definition explicitly: \(\phi = (F/A)_\text{actual} / (F/A)_\text{stoich}\). Write F/A on paper before substituting numbers.
common_mistakes.consequence: Gives the reciprocal of the correct equivalence ratio, leading to a completely wrong classification of lean vs rich mixture.

common_mistakes.mistake: Computing stoichiometric ratio using only oxygen mass (ignoring nitrogen) instead of total air mass.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They focus on O\_2 as the reactive component and forget that air includes N\_2 mass.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Always treat air as O\_2 + 3.76N\_2 when converting to mass; sum both O\_2 and N\_2 contributions.
common_mistakes.consequence: Underestimates air mass, overestimates stoichiometric F/A, and thus miscalculates \(\phi\).

common_mistakes.mistake: Using atomic weights incorrectly when computing molar mass of octane, e.g., 8×12 + 18×2 or similar errors.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Rushing through arithmetic or confusing hydrogen's atomic mass.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Write the formula clearly: C\_8H\_{18}, then compute 8×12 + 18×1 step by step.
common_mistakes.consequence: Small but significant error in stoichiometric F/A and final equivalence ratio.

common_mistakes.mistake: Misinterpreting the given fuel to air ratio 0.028 as air-to-fuel ratio.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Not reading the phrase 'fuel to air ratio' carefully; habit of seeing A/F in engine problems.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Underline 'fuel to air' in the question; if in doubt, check if the value is small (F/A) or large (A/F).
common_mistakes.consequence: Leads to using 1/0.028 in place of 0.028, giving a completely wrong \(\phi\).

mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: Phi is Fuel-heavy on top: \(\phi = F/A\,\text{actual} \div F/A\,\text{stoich}\)
mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Remembering that equivalence ratio uses fuel-to-air ratio, not air-to-fuel.
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Whenever writing the definition of equivalence ratio in combustion problems.

mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Remembering to include nitrogen mass when calculating air mass.
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: When converting stoichiometric equations with air into mass-based ratios.

flashcards.front: Define equivalence ratio \(\phi\) in terms of fuel-air mass ratios.
flashcards.back: Equivalence ratio is \(\phi = (F/A)_\text{actual} / (F/A)_\text{stoich}\), where F/A is the fuel-to-air mass ratio.

flashcards.front: For C\_xH\_y fuel, what is the general form of the stoichiometric combustion equation with air?
If \(\phi < 1\), is the mixture lean or rich? What does that mean?
flashcards.back: If \(\phi < 1\), the mixture is lean: more air (or less fuel) than stoichiometric, with excess oxygen in products.

flashcards.front: You are given 'fuel to air ratio = 0.03'. Which ratio is this and how does it enter \(\phi\)?
flashcards.back: This is F/A (fuel-to-air). Use it directly in \(\phi = (F/A)_\text{actual} / (F/A)_\text{stoich}\). Do NOT invert it.

real_world_context.application: Setting mixture strength in aircraft piston engines
real_world_context.industry_example: Pilots adjust mixture control to run slightly lean of stoichiometric (\(\phi < 1\)) during cruise for fuel economy and engine cooling.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Incorrect equivalence ratio can cause overheating, detonation, loss of power, or excessive emissions.

real_world_context.application: Combustor design in gas turbine engines
real_world_context.industry_example: Modern turbofan combustors operate at lean equivalence ratios (e.g., \(\phi \approx 0.3-0.5\)) to reduce NOx while maintaining stable flames.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Wrong estimation of \(\phi\) leads to incorrect predictions of flame temperature and pollutant formation, affecting certification and safety.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Scan for key words 'fuel to air ratio' and 'stoichiometric reaction'. If you can compute molar masses quickly, this is a straightforward 2-mark question.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If you know the given F/A is much smaller than stoichiometric (~0.06 for gasoline-like fuels), expect \(\phi < 1\) and choose an option between 0 and 1, not >1.
exam_strategy.time_management: Limit to about 2 minutes: 1 minute for molar mass and mass calculations, 1 minute to compute ratios and check units.

search_keywords: equivalence ratio fuel air ratio octane
lean and rich mixtures equivalence ratio
D.P. Mishra combustion equivalence ratio lecture

alternative_methods.name: Using generalized stoichiometric formula for CxHy
alternative_methods.description: Instead of relying on the given balanced equation, write the general stoichiometric equation for C\_8H\_{18} with air: C\_8H\_{18} + (8 + 18/4)(O\_2 + 3.76N\_2). Compute stoichiometric air requirement per 1 kmol fuel, then convert to masses and obtain (F/A)\_stoich. Finally, apply \(\phi = (F/A)_\text{actual} / (F/A)_\text{stoich}\).
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Reinforces general stoichiometry method and works even if equation is not given. Cons: Slightly longer than using the already balanced equation provided.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: Useful when the stoichiometric equation is not explicitly given or to cross-check the correctness of a provided equation.

connections_to_other_subjects.Thermodynamics: Equivalence ratio directly affects adiabatic flame temperature, which is computed using energy balance and specific heats.
connections_to_other_subjects.Heat Transfer: Flame temperature (linked to \(\phi\)) influences radiative and convective heat transfer in combustors and engine components.
connections_to_other_subjects.Environmental Engineering: Lean or rich operation (value of \(\phi\)) affects CO, NOx, and unburnt hydrocarbon emissions from engines.

deeper_dive_topics: Stoichiometric vs lean and rich combustion and their effect on adiabatic flame temperature
Equivalence ratio dependence of laminar burning velocity and flame stability
Exhaust gas analysis methods to infer actual equivalence ratio in engines
Impact of equivalence ratio on pollutant formation (NOx, CO, unburnt hydrocarbons)

syllabus_mapping.gate_subsection: Combustion and thermochemistry; stoichiometry, fuel-air ratio, equivalence ratio
syllabus_mapping.feedback_for_syllabus_design: Excellent representative question testing core combustion stoichiometry and equivalence ratio concepts with simple arithmetic.

rag_quality.notes: RAG provided detailed explanations of stoichiometric combustion, air-fuel ratio, and equivalence ratio, including an octane example and general CxHy stoichiometry. Although the exact numerical problem was not in RAG, the concepts and methods directly supported the solution. Core numerical work relied on standard combustion knowledge.

future_questions_potential: Given an equivalence ratio for octane-air mixture, compute the percentage of theoretical air supplied.
For a given equivalence ratio, estimate qualitatively how adiabatic flame temperature changes compared to stoichiometric.
Using exhaust gas composition from octane combustion, determine actual air-fuel ratio and equivalence ratio.
Extend the problem to non-ideal air composition including water vapor and analyze its effect on stoichiometric ratio.

response_json.subject: Aerospace Engineering
response_json.question_text:
Combustion between fuel (octane) and oxidizer (air) occurs inside a combustor with the following stoichiometric chemical reaction:

2C₈H₁₈ + (25O₂ + 94N₂) → 16CO₂ + 18H₂O + 94N₂.

The atomic weights of carbon (C), hydrogen (H), oxygen (O), and nitrogen (N) are 12, 1, 16, and 14, respectively. If the combustion takes place with the fuel to air ratio 0.028, then the equivalence ratio of the fuel-oxidizer mixture is
